supply_logistics.supply_status: Strained for offensive operations. Brigade now 1,800km from main depots in Egypt. Pursuit from El Alamein through Libya to Tunisia stretched supply lines severely. Fuel and ammunition prioritized for armored formations; infantry brigades receive lower allocation. Food stocks adequate but variety limited. Greek personnel morale high despite supply constraints, motivated by Allied advance toward Greece liberation. Critical shortage: spare parts for vehicles after 2,000km advance across North Africa.

weather_environment.terrain_type: Tunisian coastal plain and hills - mix of cultivated land, wadis, and rocky outcrops

Three rifle companies, HQ company - 55 casualties from pursuit operations
Three rifle companies, HQ company - 35 casualties from pursuit operations

Daimler and Humber armoured cars - 6 casualties, 2 vehicles lost

tactical_doctrine.role: Free Greek infantry brigade integrated into British 8th Army. Combat-experienced after El Alamein and pursuit operations across Libya. Now deployed in Mareth Line defensive-offensive operations in Tunisia. Equipped with British weapons and organized along British lines. Proven in defensive operations; gaining offensive experience during pursuit phase. High morale despite supply constraints - Allied advance seen as step toward liberation of Greece.
special_capabilities: Combat-proven at El Alamein - no longer green troops
High morale - fighting to liberate occupied homeland
British-trained and equipped to Commonwealth standards
Experience in desert pursuit operations (Libya advance)
Strong unit cohesion among exile forces
Adaptable to both defensive and offensive roles
tactical_innovations: Integration of Greek personnel into British command structure
Adaptation of Greek military traditions to British tactics
Lessons learned from El Alamein defensive operations applied to Tunisia
known_issues: Supply lines stretched 1,800km from Egypt - fuel/ammo constraints
Vehicle wear significant after 2,000km advance across North Africa
Anti-tank weapons obsolescent (2-pounder inadequate vs. Panzer IV/Tiger)
Equipment shortages compared to full British brigade establishment
Limited experience in Tunisian terrain (different from desert)
No replacement pipeline for Greek casualties - unit strength declining
tactical_doctrine.desert_adaptations: Extensive. Brigade gained 4 months combat/operational experience from El Alamein (Oct 1942) through pursuit to Tunisia. Fully adapted to desert conditions, vehicle maintenance in harsh environments, and extended supply lines. Now adapting to Tunisian terrain which includes more vegetation, hills, and wadis compared to Western Desert.

special_rules: High Morale: +1 to morale checks (fighting for occupied homeland)
British Equipment: Uses British Commonwealth TO&E and supply
Combat Experienced: +1 to initiative (upgraded from Regular after El Alamein/pursuit)
Supply Constrained: -1 to sustained offensive operations beyond 3 days
No Replacements: Unit cannot rebuild to full strength during campaign
Cohesion Bonus: +1 when all three battalions operating together
historical_engagements: Second Battle of El Alamein - defensive sector (23 Oct - 4 Nov 1942)
Pursuit from Egypt through Libya (Nov 1942 - Jan 1943)

precise_casualties.reason: Greek Brigade casualty records for pursuit phase (Nov 1942 - Jan 1943) not fully detailed in available sources
precise_casualties.estimate_method: Estimated 5% personnel loss (170 casualties) during 3-month pursuit operations based on British infantry brigade average attrition rates in same period. Distributed across battalions proportionally with some variation for tactical deployment differences.

vehicle_losses.reason: Precise vehicle write-offs during Libya-Tunisia advance not documented in detail for Greek Brigade
vehicle_losses.estimate_method: Estimated 10-15 truck losses from 2,000km advance based on British Commonwealth brigade averages. Armored car losses estimated at 2 vehicles based on reconnaissance role exposure.

exact_deployment_location.reason: Greek Brigade specific sector assignment within Mareth Line not confirmed in all sources - general Tunisia/Mareth area confirmed
